title: Role of Autophagy in Health
content: The fundamental role of autophagy in the maintenance of health and prevention of neurodegeneration, cancer, and other diseases. Autophagy may benefit an existing cancer cell and help it to survive—a discovery leading to new possibilities in cancer therapy. The importance of autophagy in the brain and liver. The mechanisms that can trigger autophagy to support longevity. Evidence for cancer treatment by blocking autophagy. Types of cancer that are most autophagy-dependent. The autophagy paradox. Finding a molecular signal for autophagy.

title: Fasting and Health
content: Fasting (and molecules that induce autophagy) and the critical need to decode the proper fasting “dose” in order to improve human health. Current knowledge gaps around fasting as a tool for longevity. A fasting strategy for Alzheimer’s disease prevention.

title: Molecules that Induce Autophagy
content: Rapamycin, metformin, and other molecules that may induce autophagy.

title: Studying Fasting and Exercise for Longevity
content: How to study fasting and exercise as longevity tools.

title: Autophagic Research Recognition
content: The Nobel Prize for autophagic research.

title: Future Areas of Research
content: Future study of metabolism and autophagy.

title: Alzheimer's Disease and Lifestyle Factors
content: Alzheimer's disease: Rhonda’s evolved thinking on neurodegenerative diseases. The breakdown of the blood-brain barrier in neurodegenerative disease. An explanation for the observation that type 2 diabetes increases risk of Alzheimer’s disease. The role of omega-3 fatty acids (EPA and DHA) in brain health and prevention of neurodegeneration. Comparing the preventable nature of type 2 diabetes, atherosclerosis, cancer, and dementia. Blood pressure: an important modifiable lifestyle factor that can affect Alzheimer's disease risk.

title: Exercise and Brain Health
content: Possible mechanisms by which exercise reduces the risk of Alzheimer’s disease. Building your aerobic pyramid: neurobiological effects of exercise, benefits of lactate peaks, and more. Maximizing mitochondrial biogenesis: alternative training approaches and strategies. Possible brain benefits of sauna, and Rhonda’s personal protocol. The relationship between cardiorespiratory fitness and dementia risk.

title: Exercise and Cancer Risk
content: How exercise may reduce the risk of cancer. The overarching impact of exercise on health, and the importance of focusing the factors that matter most. Impact of alcohol consumption on breast cancer risk and overall health.

title: Exercise, Sleep, and Longevity
content: Exercise as an intervention for poor sleep habits. The longevity benefits of consuming adequate protein and strength training to preserve muscle mass and strength. How to get enough of the right kind of protein in your diet.

title: Fasting and Diet
content: Fasting: weighing the risk vs. reward. How Rhonda’s views have shifted on diet and exercise.

title: Apoptosis and Cancer Prevention
content: Defining apoptosis and its role in cancer prevention. How apoptosis works. What goes wrong in a cell for it to go down the suicidal pathway. Mutations in p53 accounts for about half of all cancers. What happens post apoptosis.

title: Cancer Cells and Autophagy
content: How cancer cells use the autophagy pathway to survive.

title: Apoptosis and Autophagy in Cancer Cells
content: When apoptosis is disabled in a cancer cell, it can’t commit suicide and tumor cells become more tumorigenic. These cells turn on autophagy for survival. Autophagosomes, double membrane vesicles, are present all over the cell. Autophagy was known to exist in cells in mammals but there was almost no information on autophagy and cancer. It was hypothesized that cancer cells were using autophagy to survive. When autophagy was inhibited in cancer cells, the survival of the cancer cells was reduced. Normal cells in the fed state don’t have autophagy on, it functions at a very low level. But in cancer cells, even in the fed state, autophagy was elevated.

title: Metabolism of Cancer Cells
content: The metabolism of a cancer cell is designed to facilitate de novo synthesis of nucleotides. The autophagy pathway can eat ribosomes. Autophagy has been preserved over billions of years and is crucial for survival. The mammalian version of autophagy is a little bit more complicated and is used in more different circumstances.

title: Role of Autophagy in Starvation, Tumor Suppression, and Tumor Promotion
content: Autophagy is activated in tumors and promotes survival and growth. Loss of autophagy causes substrate accumulation, tumor cell growth arrest, senescence, and death and restricts tumor progression to benign disease. Autophagy is induced by three pathways: The mTOR pathway, which is mostly sensing amino acids, AMPK pathway, which is mostly sensing energy and ATP in general, and The Acetyl-CoA protein deacetylation pathway, which is also just basically sensing substrate of fatty acid and glucose. Additionally, stresses that result in organelle damage, activation of protein misfolding, and generation of protein aggregates can trigger autophagy.

title: Importance of Autophagy in the Brain and Liver
content: Autophagy is very important in the brain over the long term. The brain is extremely autophagy dependent. The liver is also very sensitive to autophagy. If autophagy is knocked out in the liver, it develops fatty liver disease. Autophagy plays a role in preventing fat accumulation and accumulation of mallory bodies, which are large protein aggregates composed of a protein called p62.

title: Mechanisms that can Trigger Autophagy to Support Longevity
content: Fasting is one of the most potent stimulators of autophagy. Autophagy can also be induced pharmacologically or chemically. Molecules that induce autophagy include metformin and rapamycin.

title: Evidence for Cancer Treatment by Blocking Autophagy
content: When autophagy is inhibited in an adult mouse, the mouse dies in 2-3 months from neurodegeneration. When autophagy is knocked out in a mouse with cancer, the tumor dies first. In a mouse model where autophagy can be toggled off and back on, the tissues are able to restore themselves back to normal when autophagy is turned back on.

title: Types of Cancer that are Most Autophagy-Dependent
content: Kras-driven cancers such as lung cancer and pancreatic cancer are extraordinarily autophagy dependent. The tumors are very susceptible to the functional loss of autophagy. KRAS is a GTP binding protein that is responsible for activating the MAP kinase pathway which is very key in driving cell proliferation. Cancers have mutations in RAS that leave it in the GTP-bound or on state, meaning unresponsive to cell signaling, and when you are fixed in the on position, you can’t turn off.

title: Cancer and Autophagy
content: There’s a subset of the mutations in RAS that involve a cysteine residue that there are now drugs that target that. They’ve gone downstream of RAS and targeted inhibitors of Raf, MEK, and ERK and those are actively in use in the clinic. However, they seem to be not durably effective in RAS-driven cancers because of the work-arounds. There seems to be a spectrum of sensitivity to autophagy blockade in cancers. RAS driven cancers, B-Raf driven cancers, lung cancer, melanoma, homologous recombination deficient breast cancers, APC deficient colon cancer, and prostate cancer are particularly sensitive. B-raf driven cancers are more sensitive than RAS driven lung cancers. The most sensitive cancer is RAS-Driven Lung Cancer Without LKB1.

title: Autophagy Paradox
content: Cancer utilizes autophagy to survive, but autophagy is also protective. A main function of autophagy in tissue homeostasis is to preserve cellular function to be normal, to prevent chronic damage and inflammation. Tissues that are susceptible to cancer as a result of chronic damage and inflammation, autophagy is highly protective. The role of autophagy in cancers is context-dependent. Functional autophagy can delay the onset of chronic damage and inflammation that are known causes of cancer. Stimulating autophagy through fasting or through pharmacologic means can be thought of as preserving health. But once you have a cancer, inhibiting autophagy is preferentially damaging to the tumor compared to the normal tissues.

title: Fasting and Chemotherapy
content: Fasting combined with chemotherapy might be superior to chemotherapy alone for cancer treatment. Calorie restriction takes away nutrients for the cancer to grow. Autophagy may also reduce inflammation. Fasting might be the most potent way to stimulate autophagy.

title: Autophagy in Disease Prevention and Treatment
content: Fasting might be the most potent way to stimulate autophagy. There are biotech companies working on pharmacological agents that can stimulate autophagy. However, we don’t yet have the tools to measure the signatures of autophagy. We don’t know the correct “dose” of fasting, or the minimum effective dose, to enhance autophagy and therefore get the benefits of being protected from every chronic disease.

title: Rapamycin, Metformin, and Autophagy
content: Rapamycin is a very potent inhibitor of mTOR and presumably it induces some level of autophagy. Data suggests that rapamycin is neuroprotective. It’s the only molecule that has demonstrated a longevity benefit across all four models of eukaryotic cells. The question is: By what mechanism is it producing longevity? How much of that benefit is through autophagy? How much of it is through inhibition of senescent cells? What about the reduction of inflammation?

title: Impact of Research on Human Health
content: The biomedical community has been mostly focused on putting out fires rather than disease prevention. For the quarter of a trillion dollars that has been spent on that problem over the last 50 years, we have only extended the median survival by less than about a year (on avg.) for solid organ tumors. There’s not much evidence we’ve even reduced the arrival of cancer especially given the increase in the prevalence of type 2 diabetes, insulin resistance, and all of the metabolic dysregulation.

title: Main Chronic Diseases
content: The main chronic diseases that account for most deaths in people above age 50 are cardiovascular disease, cancer, Alzheimer’s disease, and complications of diabetes. Improving metabolic health, which can be done through fasting, can reduce the risk of all of these significantly.

title: Autophagy and Cellular Senescence
content: Autophagy is good for neurodegeneration and cancer. However, there are more than likely benefits from fasting (which inducing autophagy). The benefits of fasting in cardiovascular disease are primarily mediated through the metabolic health benefits of it such as lower glucose, lower insulin, lower homocysteine in time, and lower inflammation generally.

title: Metformin and Autophagy
content: In a fed state, if we give an animal or a human metformin, it will still induce autophagy through just the AMPK activation. But, we don’t understand over the long term what the consequences of having autophagy or not having autophagy actually is.

title: Rapamycin and Autophagy
content: Rapamycin has been studied liberally in everything from yeast, flies, worms, mammals. It uniformly extends life across all those organisms. It’s also a potent inhibitor of mTOR (which would signal autophagy, all things equal). Safety is the reason it is not being more highly promoted and used as an anti-aging molecule.

title: Studying Fasting and Exercise as Longevity Tools
content: There is a need to study the most effective dose of fasting and exercise. Most people need to simply do more exercise however it would be very valuable to understand the minimum effective amount.

title: Role of Autophagy in Cancer
content: Understanding the role of autophagy in cancer involves developing small molecule inhibitors to inhibit autophagy for cancer therapy. The newest connection is the connection between autophagy and inflammation. When you turn off autophagy, you stimulate inflammation. In the context of cancer, that can be a really good thing because the game changer in cancer therapy now is immune checkpoint blockade.

title: Fasting Strategy for Alzheimer’s Disease Prevention
content: Alzheimer’s disease is a great opportunity to explore whether fasting and enhancing autophagy through various means could be beneficial in prevention. Currently, we have no way of treating/reversing AD once a person has it.

title: Prevention and Treatment of Diseases
content: If any disease demands prevention, it has to be this one. It’s hard to make the case that fasting isn’t going to play a beneficial role there. We must be fully tested to know for sure. The reason for these spectacular failures is they’re trying to treat a symptom of the disease rather than the cause of the disease.

title: Study of Metabolism and Autophagy
content: Future study of metabolism and autophagy. How autophagy impacts metabolism. Understanding in greater detail how autophagy impacts metabolism. Identify new targets for anti-cancer therapy and/or signatures of metabolic problems.

title: Immunotherapy Progress
content: Made huge progress in the field of immunotherapy and wants to keep pushing in that area.

title: Decoding Metabolism
content: The technology has advanced to the state where we can really start to understand this better. By using 13C or 15N labeled tracers, you can put them into a mouse, infuse a mouse with these tracers and by looking at where they go by mass spectrometry, over different time points, you can see metabolism. This is a growing field. It’s very exciting. And understanding metabolism in mammals at a level we’ve never seen before in various disease states is tremendous.

title: Fasting and Health
content: Interested in working on figuring out the dose effect of fasting and a signature for autophagy. Very much interested in fasting as a way to preserve health. Also interested in the dietary part, because all of this has to go together. It’s not just how many calories you eat or how often you eat them, it’s what they are.
